text: A reference to Ivan Turgenev's 1852 cycle of short stories *Notes of a Hunter* (also translated as *A Sportman's Notebook*, *The Hunting Sketches*, and *Sketches from a Hunter's Album*). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life. The "Notes" (Записки) trope is common in Russian literature: *Notes of a Rifle Hunter* (Aksakov), Notes of a Shallow Grass (Dryansky), "Notes of a Madman" (Gogol), *Notes from the Underground* (Dostoevsky), *Notes from a Dead House* (Dostoevsky), "Notes of a Madman" (Tolstoy), "Notes of a Christian" (Tolstoy), *Notes of a Doctor* (Veresaev), *Notes of a Young Doctor* (Bulgakov), *Notes of a Young Doctor* (Bulgakov), *Notes of a Psychotic* (Ven. Erofeev), and *Notes of a Nonhunter* (Vantalov).

That is, YakovThese verse segments are allegedly written by Yakov during his year on the Volga; they come divided in sections according to the time of the year, which is however never a specific season but a period between seasons. In these first Zapiski the setting is fall-winter.

text: The first chapters of the novel frequently mention fall-winter months and settings (snow, ice, etc.), while later on spring and summer will substitute them

As Boguslawski notes, the reference to chorea here is suggestive of "the time of day when the air flickers and shivers, making things blurry and difficult to identify" (Boguslawski, "Annotations" 237).

Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Plyaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).

text: The Pale Horse, the horse ridden by the Fourth Horseman of the Apocalypse, Death, in the Bible: "When the Lamb broke the fourth seal, I heard the voice of the fourth living creature saying, 'Come.' I looked, and behold, a pale horse; and he who sat on it had the name Death; and Hades was following with him. Authority was given to them over a fourth of the earth, to kill with sword and with famine and with pestilence and by the wild beasts of the earth" (Revelation 6:7–8). The color comes from the Greek "khlōros" (χλωρός), meaning greenish-yellow or pale/pallid. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/67/Gustave_Dore_-_Death_on_the_Pale_Horse.png)

Colloquial: rakish, dashing, daredevil

An opera hat. A portmanteau from шляпа (hat) and шлепок (slap, smack). The term is in turn derived from the French "chapeau claque," which combines "hat" and "click," as the hat closes with a clicking sound. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3e/Chapeauclaque.png)
Colloquial: to steal out from, sneak out

text:
The golden oriole. Русское название "иволга", по мнению лингвистов, имеет славянские корни и является однокоренным со словами «волога» и «влага». Полагают, что в древности птицу представляли как предвестницу дождя. ![](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Обыкновенная_иволга#/media/Файл:Golden_Oriole_(Oriolus_oriolus)_(43571340672).jpg) 
Here however the oriole is also chosen for its closeness to the name of the river Volga.

text: Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin (1799–1837), the father of modern Russian letters and a crucial source of subtexts in *Between Dog and Wolf*. In fact, the phrase "пора меж волка и собаки" (the time between wolf and dog) appears in Pushkin's celebrated novel-in-verse *Eugene Onegin* (ch. 4, stanza 47).
prefix:
И словно бы чего-то ждешь.
  То

text: Поэт декабрист, друг Пушкина (1798-1859)

A reference to Pushkin's poem "Autumn": "сосед мой поспешает / В отъезжие поля с охотою своей" ("and my neighbor hastens / to his far-flung fields with all the members of his hunt"). Read the poem (in Russian and in English translation) [here](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/autumn_pushkin.htm).

highlighted:
И тошно так, сказать по чести,
  Что не поможет верный эль.
  Чубук ли несколько почистить,
  
    Соседа ль вызвать на дуэль?
text: This poem merges different lines of Pushkin's oeuvre and biography (duels, spleen, etc.). In particular, this poem seems to creatively rewrite Pushkin's "Zima. Chto delat' nam v derevne?": https://www.culture.ru/poems/4915/zima-chto-delat-nam-v-derevne

A long-stemmed Turkish pipe. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/21/A_Turkish_coffee_house_on_the_Bosphorus._Edmund_Spencer_%28capt.%29._Travels_in_the_western_Causasus.1838._cover.jpg)
German: Schlafrock. A long nightgown. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1c/Pavel_Fedotov_-_The_fresh_cavalier_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)
"Задать лататы" - устойчивое выражение: стремительно убегать, без оглядки, не помня себя. Но "латка" это тоже синоним "заплата", то есть кусок ткани, нашиваемый на прорванное место.
Colloquial: to become sleepy, drowsy, fall into sleep
Set expression (to stimulate one's appetite)
Domestic servants

From the French "*cerceau*." Hoop rolling — a children's game in which hoops are kept rolling with a stick or other device. Depicted in the bottom center of the 1560 painting *Children's Games* by Bruegel: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Children%E2%80%99s_Games_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg). Ostanin also notes that Серко (Serko) is the name given to dogs in the Ukrainian fairy tale "Серко" (Ostanin, 33).

text: The transition from day to night
Colloquial: color. Used at the beginning of the chapter in Note 1 (R164/E28).

text: A reference to Pushkin's nanny, Arina Rodionovna Yakovleva (1758–1828). Pushkin dedicated several works to her. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f6/Arina_Rodionovna.jpg). In Pushkin's novel-in-verse *Eugene Onegin*, the heroine Tatiane thrice says "Ах, няня..." (ch. 3, stanzas 19, 34, 35). That's there below the portrait. :) It may also be a reference to Tatiana's nyanya from Onegin.
This set of poems deals with the time between fall and winter. Here, we move onto winter and the next batch of Notes.
